slides.title: Welcome to Bitbucket
slides.content:
# Introduction to Bitbucket ğŸª£

Bitbucket is Atlassian's **Git-based** source code repository hosting service.

## What you'll learn:
- **Pipelines** - Built-in CI/CD automation
- **Pull Requests** - Code review workflow
- **Stash/Data Center** - Enterprise deployment

> ğŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** Bitbucket was originally a Mercurial-only hosting service before adding Git support!

## Why Choose Bitbucket?

| Feature | Benefit |
|---------|--------|
| **Atlassian Integration** | Seamless Jira & Trello connection |
| **Free Private Repos** | Up to 5 team members |
| **Built-in CI/CD** | Pipelines included |
| **Branch Permissions** | Granular access control |
| **Code Insights** | Quality and security reports |

## Bitbucket Products

- â˜ï¸ **Bitbucket Cloud** - SaaS offering
- ğŸ¢ **Bitbucket Data Center** - Self-managed enterprise
- ğŸ“¦ **Bitbucket Server** (legacy) - Now Data Center

Let's explore Bitbucket!

slides.title: Your First Pipeline
slides.content:
# Creating Your First Pipeline ğŸ“

Create `bitbucket-pipelines.yml` in your repository root:

```yaml
image: node:20

pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        name: Build and Test
        caches:
          - node
        script:
          - npm ci
          - npm test
          - npm run build
        artifacts:
          - dist/**

  branches:
    main:
      - step:
          name: Build
          script:
            - npm ci
            - npm run build
      - step:
          name: Deploy to Production
          deployment: production
          script:
            - pipe: atlassian/rsync-deploy:0.4.0
              variables:
                USER: $DEPLOY_USER
                SERVER: $DEPLOY_SERVER
                REMOTE_PATH: /var/www/app
                LOCAL_PATH: dist/
```

## Pipeline Structure

| Component | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| `image` | Default Docker image |
| `pipelines` | Pipeline definitions |
| `default` | Runs on all branches |
| `branches` | Branch-specific pipelines |
| `step` | Individual build step |

slides.title: Pipeline Configuration
slides.content:
# Advanced Pipeline Configuration âš™ï¸

## Step Options

```yaml
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        name: My Step
        image: python:3.11  # Override default image
        size: 2x            # Double resources
        max-time: 30        # Timeout in minutes
        script:
          - echo "Running..."
        after-script:
          - echo "Cleanup..."
        artifacts:
          - build/**
        caches:
          - pip

    - parallel:  # Run steps in parallel
        - step:
            name: Unit Tests
            script:
              - pytest tests/unit
        - step:
            name: Integration Tests
            script:
              - pytest tests/integration
```

## Trigger Types

```yaml
pipelines:
  # On push to any branch
  default:
    - step:
        script: echo "Default"

  # On pull request
  pull-requests:
    '**':
      - step:
          script: echo "PR build"

  # On tag
  tags:
    'v*':
      - step:
          script: echo "Release $BITBUCKET_TAG"

  # Custom pipelines (manual trigger)
  custom:
    deploy-staging:
      - step:
          script: echo "Deploying to staging"
```

slides.title: Pipes in Bitbucket
slides.content:
# Bitbucket Pipes ğŸ”Œ

Pipes are **pre-built integration** scripts for common tasks.

## Using Pipes

```yaml
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        script:
          - npm run build
          - pipe: atlassian/aws-s3-deploy:1.1.0
            variables:
              AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: $AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID
              AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: $AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY
              AWS_DEFAULT_REGION: us-east-1
              S3_BUCKET: my-bucket
              LOCAL_PATH: dist/
```

## Popular Pipes

| Pipe | Purpose |
|------|--------|
| `aws-s3-deploy` | Deploy to S3 |
| `aws-ecs-deploy` | Deploy to ECS |
| `azure-web-apps-deploy` | Deploy to Azure |
| `google-cloud-storage-deploy` | Deploy to GCS |
| `slack-notify` | Send Slack messages |
| `npm-publish` | Publish to npm |
| `docker-push` | Push Docker images |

## Finding Pipes

1. Visit Bitbucket Pipelines editor
2. Click **Add a pipe**
3. Browse categories or search
4. Copy configuration to your YAML

> ğŸ’¡ **Tip:** Pipes simplify complex integrations to a few lines of YAML!

## Creating a Pull Request

1. Push your feature branch
2. Click **Create pull request** in Bitbucket
3. Fill in details:
   - Title and description
   - Reviewers
   - Close branch option
4. Submit for review

## PR Features

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| **Inline Comments** | Comment on specific lines |
| **Tasks** | Create actionable items |
| **Approvals** | Require reviewer sign-off |
| **Merge Checks** | Block on failing builds |
| **Diff View** | Side-by-side or unified |

slides.title: Code Review Features
slides.content:
# Code Review in Bitbucket ğŸ‘€

## Adding Comments

### Line Comments
- Click the line number to add comments
- Comments appear in the diff view
- Mark as resolved when addressed

### File Comments
- Add comments at the file level
- Use for general file feedback

### General Comments
- Discussion not tied to specific code
- Visible in the activity tab

## Tasks

Turn comments into actionable items:

```
Comment: "Please add error handling here"
         [Create task]

Task appears in:
- PR overview
- Tasks tab
- Merge check (optional)
```

## Approval Workflow

| Action | Meaning |
|--------|--------|
| âœ… **Approve** | Code looks good |
| âŒ **Request changes** | Must fix before merge |
| ğŸ‘€ **Unapprove** | Withdraw approval |

## Merge Strategies

- **Merge commit** - Preserve all commits
- **Squash** - Combine into one commit
- **Fast-forward** - Linear history only

> ğŸ¯ **Best Practice:** Require at least one approval before merging!

# Bitbucket Data Center ğŸ¢

**Bitbucket Data Center** (formerly Stash) is Atlassian's **self-managed** Git solution.

## Cloud vs Data Center

| Feature | Cloud | Data Center |
|---------|-------|-------------|
| Hosting | Atlassian managed | Self-managed |
| Updates | Automatic | Manual |
| Customization | Limited | Extensive |
| Compliance | Atlassian controls | You control |
| Scale | Up to 5000 users | Unlimited |
| Cost | Per user/month | Annual license |

- ğŸ“‹ **Compliance** - Meet regulatory requirements

slides.title: Pipeline Variables and Secrets
slides.content:
# Variables and Secrets ğŸ”

## Variable Types

### Repository Variables
- Available to all pipelines in the repo
- Set in Repository settings â†’ Pipelines â†’ Variables

### Workspace Variables
- Shared across all repos in workspace
- Set in Workspace settings â†’ Pipelines â†’ Variables

### Deployment Variables
- Environment-specific values
- Set per deployment environment

## Using Variables

```yaml
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        script:
          # Repository variable
          - echo $MY_VARIABLE
          
          # Secured variable (masked in logs)
          - ./deploy.sh --key $SECRET_KEY
          
          # Built-in variables
          - echo "Branch: $BITBUCKET_BRANCH"
          - echo "Commit: $BITBUCKET_COMMIT"
          - echo "Repo: $BITBUCKET_REPO_SLUG"
```

## Built-in Variables

| Variable | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| `BITBUCKET_COMMIT` | Current commit SHA |
| `BITBUCKET_BRANCH` | Branch name |
| `BITBUCKET_TAG` | Tag name (if tagged) |
| `BITBUCKET_PR_ID` | Pull request ID |
| `BITBUCKET_BUILD_NUMBER` | Build number |

> âš ï¸ **Security:** Mark sensitive values as "Secured" to mask in logs!

slides.title: Code Insights
slides.content:
# Code Insights ğŸ“Š

Code Insights displays **quality and security reports** directly on PRs.

## Available Insights

| Insight | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| **Test Results** | Unit test pass/fail |
| **Code Coverage** | Coverage percentage |
| **Security Scan** | Vulnerability reports |
| **Linting** | Code style issues |
| **Dependencies** | Outdated packages |

## Configuring Test Reports

```yaml
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        name: Test
        script:
          - npm test -- --reporter=junit --outputFile=test-results.xml
        after-script:
          - pipe: atlassian/checkstyle-report:0.4.0
```

## Coverage Reports

```yaml
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        script:
          - npm test -- --coverage
          - pipe: atlassian/codecov-report:1.0.0
            variables:
              CODECOV_TOKEN: $CODECOV_TOKEN
```

## Third-Party Integrations

- **SonarQube** - Code quality
- **Snyk** - Security scanning
- **Codecov** - Coverage tracking
- **ESLint** - JavaScript linting

> ğŸ’¡ **Benefit:** See quality issues before merging!
